title: Which religion came to existence first, Christianity or Islam? - Quora

response.answer_text: As John Bartram and Nicolas Garcia point out, the date of emergence of Christianity is not as clear as most Christians want to believe. Yeshua ben Yusef was a radical rabbit and a pioneer of passive resistance. He taught to the Jews who were his people. Not just theology but resistance techniques such as turning the other cheek and walking another mile. Along with loving your enemies, these ideas seem to have originatde in Hinduism and point to the possibility that Yeshua may have travelled to India, most likely as a journeyman carpenter working his way as a ship’s carpenter. (It is seemingly no accident or whim that led Thomas the Skeptic [or “Doubting Thomas] to set up the church in modern-day Kerala State in India as early as 53AD, as the story has it). Saul (or Paul) of Tarsus created the notion of Jesus (the Greek translation of Yeshua) the Messiah and element of a divine Trinity. That was some time after the death of Yeshua. The Trinity was a core element of the Olympian pantheon, but not of Jewish tradition. Saul/Paul also made a significant break with other followers of Yeshua by teaching to Gentiles and weaving into the religion elements from both Greek and Roman theological traditions. This made it easier to spread through the Empire. In 325 AD Roman Emperor Constantine convened the Council of Nicea, purportedly to bring together the various “Christian” traditions but in reality more to bring them under the control of Rome and to extirpate teachings that were seditious to the Roman Empire. The notion of Jesus as divine was a key element in this establishment of the religion because it needed to key into existing Roman theological frameworks but to replace the deified Emperors with a semi-mythical person deified. It was also important to blame the Jews for the Crucifixion of Jesus, despite its having been done by the Romans, so the story of a Jewish Rabbi was used as an excuse for genocidal attacks on the Jewish people by Christians for more than a millenium. It was towards the end of the Twentieth Century that the leader of the Roman Church finally refuted that idea. As John Bartram points out in this thread, further changes were made over the next century or two that brought “Christianity” to what came to be known as Roman Catholicism after the Reformation. So Christianity would seem to be older than Islam, but possibly not by all that much. However Islam can be seen as a relatively mild reworking of older theological ideas including many that are almost certain to have been part of some of the Pre-Nicean threads of Christianity. We might even see both Islam and Christianity as co-descendants of the teachings of Jesus filtered through different cultures and theological traditions. In that light they might be seen as being of equal age, although that is bound to be a fringe view.
